item.title: Singapore Tightens Property Measures to Cool Housing Market
item.description: Singapore introduced fresh measures to tame housing prices, raising the stamp duty for those who sell their private homes within four years.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Tan

item.title: Levain Bakery Inside Inflation
item.description: One company has firsthand that has a firsthand perspective on all this is Levine Bakery. It started out as a small bread shop on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, and it's now it has expanded over the past 30 years to 16 bakery locations and counting across the U.S. And now I'm told you can actually find some of their products in grocery store. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Archegos Employees Entitled to $33 Million, Judge Says
item.description: A federal judge ruled that a group of former Archegos Capital Management employees, including an analyst who worked closely with founder Bill Hwang, are owed $33 million for losses they suffered when the firm collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Bill Hwang, founder of Archegos Capital Management, exits federal court in New York, US, on Monday, July 8, 2024. Hwang's fate will soon be in the hands of the jury, with both the prosecution and defense set to make closing arguments in his fraud and market manipulation trial.

item.title: Apollo-Backed Athora Offers $7.8 Billion for UK Insurer PICG
item.description: A European insurance group backed by Apollo Global Management Inc. offered to acquire a specialist UK insurer that’s partly owned by a company controlled by South African billionaire Johann Rupert for about £5.7 billion ($7.8 billion).
item.dc:creator: Prinesha Naidoo, Khuleko Siwele

item.title: Zimbabwe Has Nationwide Blackout as System Failure Cripples Grid
item.description: Zimbabwe suffered a countrywide electricity outage on Thursday due to a system failure that resulted in loss of generation at its two power stations.
item.dc:creator: Godfrey Marawanyika

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk along a street at dusk in the central business district of Harare, Zimbabwe, on Monday, Feb. 12, 2024. Zimbabwe may back its currency with gold in an effort to end exchange-rate instability, Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube said.

item.title: China Shuns US Oil for Longest Stretch Since 2018
item.description: China avoided purchasing US crude for the third straight month — the longest stretch since 2018 — delivering a fresh blow to shale drillers already facing lower oil prices.
item.dc:creator: Lucia Kassai

media:content.media:description: The Valero Houston refinery in Houston, Texas, US, on Monday June 23, 2025. Efforts to de-escalate the Middle East conflict spurred a selloff in oil, easing concerns about inflation and driving stocks higher on hopes the Federal Reserve will have room to cut rates despite Jerome Powell's wait-and-see signals.

item.title: Stew Leonard’s Tips on Saving Money for Fourth of July
item.description: Stew Leonard Jr., President & CEO of Stew Leonard’s, tells Open Interest that despite uncertainty from tariffs, consumer are feeling good about the economy. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fed’s Bostic Says Economy Provides Space for Patience
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic urged patience amid uncertainty over economic policy, saying, “I believe a period characterized by such widespread uncertainty is no time for significant shifts in monetary policy.” Bostic said Thursday at an event in Frankfurt that a wait-and-see approach can help to ensure officials don’t have to reverse course on interest rates.

item.title: Glencore Has Ownership Clause for Troubled UK Refinery Lindsey
item.description: Commodity trading giant Glencore Plc has a clause in its supply agreement with Prax Lindsey Oil Refinery Ltd. enabling it to take control of its facility in northern England if the debt it’s owed isn’t repaid.
item.dc:creator: Archie Hunter

media:content.media:description: The Prax Lindsey Oil Refinery is pictured in North Killingholme, north east England on October 4, 2021. - The British military started delivering fuel to petrol stations on Monday, after a tanker driver shortage sparked two weeks of panic-buying by motorists and emptied pumps. (Photo by Lindsey Parnaby / AFP) (Photo by LINDSEY PARNABY/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: UK Bond Bulls Unfazed by Latest Bout of Market Turmoil
item.description: While many investors were fretting over the potential for UK fiscal instability this week, some saw an opportunity to load up on government bonds.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Tajitsu, Alice Gledhill

media:content.media:description: Visitors at Canary Wharf financial, business and shopping district in London.

item.title: Alibaba Offers $1.5 Billion of Ali Health Exchangeable Bonds
item.description: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. is seeking to raise HK$12 billion ($1.5 billion) from the sale of bonds exchangeable into shares of Alibaba Health Information Technology Ltd.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti

media:content.media:description: Signage at the Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. headquarters in Hangzhou, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Deutsche Glasfaser Turns to Preferred Equity to Tempt Investors
item.description: German telecommunications company Deutsche Glasfaser is seeking to lure investors with better terms in its €1 billion ($1.2 billion) fundraising process, after an initial push to raise common equity fell flat.
item.dc:creator: Arno Schuetze, Libby Cherry, Giulia Morpurgo

media:content.media:description: Fiber optic cable casings in Berlin.

item.title: All of Your ‘ZIRP Era’ Comments Sound Ridiculous Now
item.description: Hello and welcome to the newsletter, a grab bag of daily content from the Odd Lots universe. Sometimes it's us, Joe Weisenthal and Tracy Alloway, bringing you our thoughts on the most recent developments in markets, finance and the economy. And sometimes it's contributions from our network of expert guests and sources. Whatever it is, we promise it will always be interesting.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: The H3 rocket, built by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. for Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), lifts up at Tanegashima Space Center in Kagoshima, Japan, on Saturday, Feb. 17, 2024. Japan has launched its flagship rocket in what could be a turning point for a battered space program struggling to overcome recent setbacks and compete with Elon Musk’s SpaceX. Photographer: Nicholas Takahashi/Bloomberg

item.title: Nigeria’s GTBank Raises $105 Million in London Share Sale
item.description: Guaranty Trust Holding Co., the parent company of Nigeria’s biggest lender by market value, raised $105 million in its first international share sale, a prelude to its listing on the London Stock Exchange.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Osae-Brown, Emele Onu

media:content.media:description: The London Stock Exchange. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: State Street Sees Enormous Movement into ETFs
item.description: Yie-Hsin Hung, State Street Investment Management CEO, joins Open Interest to discuss volatility, US exceptionalism, and the demand for stablecoins. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Energy-Efficient Chipmaker Ambiq Micro Files for US IPO
item.description: Ambiq Micro Inc., a maker of ultra-low power semiconductors, has filed for an initial public offering as tech companies try to address the power consumption challenges posed by artificial intelligence computing.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: Technicians perform production control tasks in the cleanroom during the semiconductor manufacturing process.

item.title: Rivian, Lucid to Benefit From Trump Tax Bill, BNP Paribas Says
item.description: Shares of Rivian Automotive Inc. and Lucid Group Inc. gained as much as 4.6% and 8.8%, respectively, on Thursday as BNP Paribas sees the EV makers benefiting from President Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill ending electric vehicle tax credits.
item.dc:creator: Monique Mulima

media:content.media:description: Rivian R1S and R1T electric vehicles at a dealership and service center in San Francisco.

item.title: Colombia Eyes ‘Unprecedented’ Franc Loans to Ease Debt Costs
item.description: Colombia is seeking to borrow as much as $10 billion in Swiss francs to fund the repurchase of more expensive liabilities in a bid to rein in the nation’s burgeoning debt service costs.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

item.title: State Street's Hung Sees 'Tremendous' Demand for Private Markets
item.description: Yie-Hsin Hung, State Street Investment Management CEO, says the second half of the year will be good for US equities and discusses the latest trends in private markets. Speaking with Sonali Basak and Matt Miller on "Bloomberg Open Interest," Hung also comments on how stablecoins could impact the Treasury market. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 7/3/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Falls in Choppy Trading on Report US to Restart Iran Talks
item.description: Oil declined after Axios reported the US plans to restart nuclear talks with Iran, reducing the risk of another flare-up in the Middle East conflict.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: A refinery in Houston, Texas. Photographer: Mark Felix/Bloomberg

item.title: Latin American VC Activity Slows to Near Pre-Pandemic Lows
item.description: Venture capital dealmaking in Latin America has hit the slowest pace in almost seven years, in part due to global economic uncertainty and a pullback from US investors in the region.
item.dc:creator: Maria Clara Cobo

item.title: The Great Bitcoin Power Shift Has Large Holders Dumping 500,000 Coins
item.description: A silent transfer of control is reshaping the $2.1 trillion Bitcoin market.
item.dc:creator: Olga Kharif

item.title: Summit Is in Talks for $15 Billion Partnership With AstraZeneca
item.description: AstraZeneca Plc is discussing a partnership deal with Summit Therapeutics Inc. in which it could pay as much as $15 billion over time to license a lung-cancer drug, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Michelle F Davis, Dinesh Nair

media:content.media:description: The AstraZeneca facility in Gaithersburg, Maryland.

item.title: China Vows to Increase Oversight of Wayward Solar Sector
item.description: The Chinese government vowed to increase oversight of the nation’s beleaguered solar industry, which has suffered billions of dollars in losses as an over-abundance of manufacturing capacity slashes prices.
item.dc:creator: Dan Murtaugh

media:content.media:description: A worker produces photovoltaic modules for solar panels in a factory in Suqian, China.

item.title: Malaysia’s Petronas Signs Second LNG Deal With Venture Global
item.description: Malaysian energy company Petroliam Nasional Bhd., known as Petronas, has signed a new 20-year deal for liquefied natural gas supply from Venture Global Inc., marking a significant sales and purchase agreement for the US exporter.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Liao

item.title: Hedge Fund Giants Forge Into 2nd Half With Fresh Gains
item.description: The biggest hedge funds sailed smoothly through a chaotic start to their year, even adding to their gains in June despite the heightened war risk and ongoing tariff uncertainty. Bloomberg's Chief Hedge Funds Correspondent Nishant Kumar joined Wall Street Beat on Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the hedge fund strategies that delivered. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: New Jersey Shore School Threatens Bankruptcy Over Tax Spat
item.description: A New Jersey school district is threatening to file bankruptcy after years of state funding cuts, escalating a showdown with Governor Phil Murphy’s administration and causing outstanding debt to sell off.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright, Sri Taylor

item.title: Volatility Gauge Hovers Near Lowest In Four Months on Strong Jobs Data
item.description: The Cboe VIX Index touched its lowest level in more than four months in early trading Thursday, after jobs data showing the US labor market is doing better than expected added to a rally that has pushed stocks to records.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder

media:content.media:description: Traders work in the Cboe Volatility Index options pit at the Cboe Global Markets exchange in Chicago.

item.title: Cartel Money Crackdown Has Mexican Banks Reeling From Sanctions
item.description: Top bank executives gathered at a luxury resort off Mexico’s Pacific coast encountered an unexpected guest at an annual convention in May. A high-level official with the US Treasury Department had flown down to the soiree — where rooms ran as much as $900 a night — to deliver a firm warning.
item.dc:creator: Michael O'Boyle, Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Intercam Banco headquarters in Mexico City. Photographer: Stephania Corpi/Bloomberg
